title: That's quite an increase in origin complexity.
body:
Now we have a born shuriman who volunteered in the noxian military, deserted during the invasion of ionia and is now on her way back to Shurima to defeat the evil Bird God that has risen from the grave, but has to take a detour over the Freljord to get past the Noxian territory.

Well, that’s quite a step up if you compare this to early lore…

Not complaining, I'm all for more depth and complexity, but it surely is a difference.

What's more interesting is the way it's crafted. It's a heroe's journey through three entirely different areas to save her family from the great evil. Ironically, Azir has probably zero business with enslaving people. He would probably invite all shurimans to live in the city, to fill it with life again. Full citicen rights and all. Heck, he would probably welcome her with open arms...

Also I get the feeling our rock-bending bird might cause quite some trouble during the Freljordian Civil War. Maybe we finally get some more lore from there too?

We have to keep in mind that both Freljord and Shurima are both falling into the "unfinished events" category. And now we have a champion who will travel both areas. Truly interesting...

Ironically, Azir definitely doesn't want to enslave anyone. Before he was destroyed, he actually freed every single slave in all of Shurima. So no, he's not going to enslave anyone.
People mistake sand soldiers for people. Theres azirs slaves. His memory

That grammar though...
But anyway, no. He freed all the slaves, and the sand soldiers are memories of ancient soldiers, not slaves.

I know they arent slave's but im saying to a person looking from a distance if you see a birdman controlling people to (example) rebuild a city day and night without question What would you think? Kind king with devoted citizens? Or evil creature controlling slaves? (note: his powers aren't limited to soldiers but anyone in his memory)

I think the real reason as to why everyone thinks he is enslaving people is because only him, Nasus, Renekton, and Xerath know about the freeing of the slaves. Everyone else is dead and the records were wiped out in an arcane blast. So of course no one knows about it, which is why everyone thinks there's gonna be slaves.
To be fair, Azir took his sweet time with the slave-freeing.  It's not like he got rid of 'em the moment he could.

Well, when an economy is built on a strong slave-trade, abolishing slavery in a single moment, without preparation, would toss the empire's stability right out the window. More than likely, Azir was taking time during his rule to actually set up the Shuriman Empire in such a way that it could function _without_ slaves.

That, and he wanted Xerath to be the first person to know that he is abolishing slavery. Because Xerath was his friend and he cared about him. He thought he deserved to be the first person to know that he is free. On top of the whole empire stability thing.

If I recall correctly, Azir isn't quite so benign as people want to believe.  He has a vision, and it is going to be his way or die.  He is the emperor, after all.  I don't see wandering desert tribes falling in line just because he says so and believes he is the ruler based on ancient history.

I also am slightly concerned about how much impact this character's journey will affect these ongoing stories.  Will her appearance in Freljord (and, presumably, any events she catalyzes) take away from another, already Freljordian character who could create the same changes?  There is a balance there, as the Freljord issues shouldn't be just contained to those champs who hail from the area, but introducing newcomers risks overshadowing other characters that have more of a connection to the events.

"WELL THERE; primitive tribe people. Do you want to keep living in your unsave village or your caravan camps, constantly threatened by voidbreed, bandits or sandstorms while having to drink dirty water from a half-drained well? Or do you want to live in this rad city I have that can offer you protection from bandits and sandstorms while supplying you with clean oasis water? Also, I have an army of infinite sand soldiers to prevent ANYONE from ever brning harm to us."

I doubt that there are many village clans that would not take that chance...

First of all he looks like an old god right out of Shuriman culture - and he can back that up with immense powers. I can see why people would follow him.

I'm not saying people won't follow him.  I'm just pointing out he is not righteous or inclined to democracy/listening to other people's ideas or concerns.  He has a plan, if you do not accept that plan (which involves being told what to do) then you are swept away.  A lot of independent tribesmen will probably not want to be told what to do by someone who has not earned their respect, even if they do recognize his power.

The point is that everyone seems to be taking the whole "evil brid-god enslaving people" as rumor and completely untrue.  All I'm saying is that it isn't out of character for Azir.  There will probably be conflict between him and the tribes.  Yes he wants to restore the glory of his empire (which brought up the quality of life for most people in the region) but he is also pharaoh like in his ruling, and having a lord over you when you've been free your entire life (and for uncounted generations past) is not something you just accept for some cleaner water.

Uhh, you do realize that Runeterra has like, almost ZERO experience with democracy? In this world it is entirely NORMAL to rule or be ruled. And if you're smart you eithe rrule or pick a chill ruler. Noxus is a military regime, Demacia is an absolutistic monarchy. Shurima is tribal area, Ionia has village elders making the rules in a council. Shadow Isles are dead. Bilgewater is anarchy that has to be kept forcefully down by a brutal ruler. 

Only Zaun and Piltover are POTENTIALLY democratic, if they don#t turn out to be technocraties.

For people it would be entirely normal to follow someone who claims to be king and can back that up somehow.

Ok, leave democratic out of it.  Bad choice of words on my part.  My point still stands - he isn't a nice ruler who wants the best for his people.  He wants his empire back, both to restore his glory and to prove he is ascended and powerful.  If he has to enslave entire villages to build monuments to his hubris, he can and will.  We don't know what the culture was like in the first empire, but chances are it was like ancient Egypt (since they're similar).  The rulers there built huge monuments that required cities full of slaves working over a lifetime to complete.  I don't think people, especially free-roving tribes in the desert, will completely change their lifestyle just because some legendary bird god appeared and asked them to build stuff for him (possibly with threats of enslavement if they don't agree)

"As a tribesman, I give my loyalty to the elders of my tribe because I know them and trust their judgment.  When I am older, I will be an elder.  This bird dude out there?  Why should I trust him?  He wants me to haul stones around and crowd into one place with all those other people.  I want to remain free and wandering the dunes.  

Oh, he says he is King.  OK then, time to blindly follow him."

I really don't see that happening.

If it's a monumnent he could just build it himself. He restored the entire capital within minutes, so I doubt he would need any slaves for that. An empire is not just a mass of people or monuments. It's the population, the culture, the economy, the trading, its army - everything that makes it actually significant. 

A bunch of slaves is not an empire. And Azir knows that as well.

Well, they might have sworn loyality to their elders but... 

"Hey this man offers us water, shelter, safety from the deserts dangers, and food, as well as a chance of an economic miracle and and massive improvement of living standard." - that might not be exactly what they said, but that's what many might think.

On top of that there is the entire religious&cultural aspect. They know their country had been the largest and most powerful empire in the past. And now, the symbol of that, the lost capital, has returned. It's a miracle. A sign from the gods. And most of it all: a chance to be part of something that might be the most glorious empire in all of Valoran, even bigger than Demacia or Noxus, as this one seems to have divine protection.

It's kinda easy to see why this might have some attraction for people.
